V3: Description
version_mixs_sc_rnaseq
Single-cell Ribonucleic Acid Sequencing (scRNA-Seq) [Minimum Information about any (x) Sequence (MIxS)]
For single cell RNA-seq studies with a focus on the essential contextual details for the sampling and sequencing of genomic data.
mixs
sc_rnaseq
Official name of the study or project. Project title should be fewer than 30 words, such as a title of a grant proposal or a publication.
V4: e.g. Study of single cells in the human body

V3: A detailed description of the project which includes research goals and experimental approach. Project description should be fewer than 300 words, such as an abstract from a grant application or publication.
V4: e.g. This project explores the intricate details of single cells in the human body, focusing on their structure, function, and behaviour. By studying individual cells, it aims to uncover how they contribute to overall health, disease progression, and human biology. This research can provide deeper insights into cellular processes, paving the way for advancements in medical treatments and personalised medicine.

V3: The workflow or protocol followed during the study.
The sorting or visualisation technology used.
The substance or equipment used as a negative control in an investigation
The substance, mixture, product, or apparatus used to verify that a process which is part of an investigation delivers a true positive

Variable aspects of an experiment design that can be used to describe an experiment, or set of experiments, in an increasingly detailed manner. This field accepts ontology terms from Experimental Factor Ontology (EFO) and/or Ontology for Biomedical Investigations (OBI)
A related resource that is referenced, cited, or otherwise associated to the sequence.
A 16-digit number that uniquely identify researchers.
A first name (or given name) is the personal name given to an individual conducting the study.
A last name (or surname) is the family name passed down from one generation to the next for the individual conducting the study.
A unique identifier used to send and receive electronic messages (emails) over the internet.
An organisation or institution that this person is associated with.
A person or organization that supports (sponsors) something through some kind of financial contribution.
A grant that directly or indirectly provides funding or sponsorship for the person to conduct the study.
A unique alphanumeric reference or identifier for the study.
Report the host's taxonomic name and/or NCBI taxonomy ID
The full scientific name of the species studied.
An identifier of the strain of the organism, if applicable.
The type of tissue sampled for the study.

The time of sampling, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008; Except: 2008-01; 2008 all are ISO8601 compliant
The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees, limited to 8 decimal points, and in WGS84 system

Report the major environmental system the sample or specimen came from. The system(s) identified should have a coarse spatial grain, to provide the general environmental context of where the sampling was done (e.g. in the desert or a rainforest). Reference: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.
Report the environmental material(s) immediately surrounding the sample or specimen at the time of sampling.
Report the environmental material(s) immediately surrounding the sample or specimen at the time of sampling.
A unique alphanumeric reference or identifier assigned to the sample in the study related to NCBI Taxonomy.

The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name followed by specific region name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/GAZ)
The vertical distance below local surface. For sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectively. Depth can be reported as an interval for subsurface samples

Elevation of the sampling site is its height above a fixed reference point, most commonly the mean sea level. Elevation is mainly used when referring to points on the earth's surface, while altitude is used for points above the surface, such as an aircraft in flight or a spacecraft in orbit
The total amount or size (volume (ml), mass (g) or area (m2) ) of sample collected
Specific enrichment or screening methods applied before and/or after creating libraries
List of database(s) used for ORF annotation, along with version number and reference to website or publication
Temperature of the sample at the time of sampling in degree celsius
Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation and growth condition specifications of the organism/material

Heights of objects such as airplanes, space shuttles, rockets, atmospheric balloons and heights of places such as atmospheric layers and clouds in metres (m). It is used to measure the height of an object which is above the earth's surface. In this context, the altitude measurement is the vertical distance between the earth's surface above sea level and the sampled position in the air

A unique identifier assigned to a material sample used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field.

The ploidy level of the genome (e.g. allopolyploid, haploid, diploid, triploid, tetraploid). It has implications for the downstream study of duplicated gene and regions of the genomes (and perhaps for difficulties in assembly)
To what is the entity pathogenic
The type of reproduction from the parent stock. Values for this field is specific to different taxa.
The device used to collect an environmental sample.
Description of relationship(s) between the subject organism and other organism(s) it is associated with.
Primary publication if isolated before genome publication; otherwise, primary genome report
The phylogenetic marker(s) used to assign an organism name to the SAG or MAG
Trophic levels are the feeding position in a food chain. Microbes can be a range of producers (e.g. chemolithotroph)

Information about the genetic distinctness of the sequenced organism below the subspecies level, e.g., serovar, serotype, biotype, ecotype, or any relevant genetic typing schemes like Group I plasmid. Subspecies should not be recorded in this term, but in the NCBI taxonomy. Supply both the lineage name and the lineage rank separated by a colon, e.g., biovar:abc123

List of diseases with which the host has been diagnosed; can include multiple diagnoses. The value of the field depends on host; for humans the terms should be chosen from the DO (Human Disease Ontology) at https://www.disease-ontology.org, non-human host diseases are free text
The method employed for collecting the sample
NCBI taxon id of the sample. Maybe be a single taxon or mixed taxa sample. Use 'synthetic metagenome for mock community/positive controls, or 'blank sample' for negative controls
Method used for taxonomic classification, along with reference database used, classification rank, and thresholds used to classify new genomes
A unique alphanumeric code for the dissociation protocol in the study
A descriptive name of the protocol used for single-cell sequencing.
V4: e.g. 10X Genomics Single Cell 3' Library Prep

V3: A free-text description of the process used to separate cells from tissues or cell aggregates.
V4: e.g. Tissue was enzymatically dissociated using collagenase for 30 minutes.

V3: Description of the specificity markers used to isolate cell populations, e.g. 'CD45+'. Please contact FAANG DCC to add more terms.
The kit used to isolate the cells.
V4: e.g. BD Rhapsody Single-Cell Analysis System

V3: Reference to literature sources that describe the protocol or methods used.
V4: e.g. Doe et al. (2024), 'Single-cell RNA-seq: A comprehensive overview'

V3: Reference link to protocols.io for additional details on the protocol.
Reference to the Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) in workflow hub.
The method used to dissociate tissues into single cells.
Metrics used to assess the quality of single cells before sequencing.
A unique alphanumeric reference or identifier assigned to the cell suspension for the sample in the study.
A unique alphanumeric code for the dissociation protocol in the study
A unique alphanumeric code for the cell suspension for the sample
The type of suspension used to keep cells in solution during processing.
An number representing the number of cells in the sequencing library.
The percentage of living cells in a sample, indicating the health and quality of cells for RNA-sequencing analysis.
The method used to evaluate the viability of cells in the sample, often involving staining or flow cytometry techniques.
The size of the cell, typically measured in micrometres.
The volume of the cell suspension in microlitres (µL).
The concentration of cells in the suspension in microlitres (µL).
The dilution factor of the cell suspension.
The volume of the cell suspension loaded into the single-cell RNA-sequencing system for analysis.

A solution used to dilute cell suspensions to a desired concentration, typically prior to loading cells into a device for single-cell RNA sequencing. It helps maintain cell viability and integrity during processing.
V4: e.g. PBS (Phosphate-buffered saline) with 0.04% BSA (Bovine serum albumin)

V3: A unique alphanumeric reference or identifier for the library preparation protocol used during the sequencing.
A unique alphanumeric code for the cell suspension for the library preparation.

Packaged kits (containing adapters, indexes, enzymes, buffers etc.), tailored for specific sequencing workflows, which allow the simplified preparation of sequencing-ready libraries for small genomes, amplicons, and plasmids
The version number of the library preparation kit used for sequencing.
The method used to amplify the Complementary DNA (cDNA).
The number of cycles used during the Complementary DNA (cDNA) amplification process.
The average length of RNA fragments in base pairs (BP) after library preparation, indicating the quality and suitability of the RNA for sequencing.
The library construction method (including version) that was used.
The specific fraction of biological macromolecule from which the sequencing library is derived.
The type of primer used for reverse transcription. This allows users to identify content of the cDNA library input for mRNA.
The end from which the molecule was sequenced.
The end bias of the library.
The Complementary DNA (cDNA) strand of the library from which the reads derived from - sense (first), antisense (second), both or none.
External RNA added to the sample as a control to assess technical variability and normalization in RNA-sequencing. State whether spike-in was used.
The specific type of external RNA used for spiking in, often indicating the source or nature of the control RNA.
The final concentration or dilution (for commercial sets) of the spike in mix.
Barcode sequence used on the i5 adapter during library preparation for identifying samples in multiplexed single-cell RNA-sequencing.
Barcode sequence used on the i7 adapter to distinguish samples in multiplexed sequencing runs.
Specifies if both i5 and i7 indices (dual) or only one index (single) was used for sample identification during sequencing.
The nucleotide sequence of the i5 index used in multiplexing during sequencing.
The specific nucleotide sequence of the i7 index used for a sample.
Identifier for the 96-well plate used in sample preparation.
The row identifier in a 96-well plate indicating the sample's position.
The column identifier in a 96-well plate indicating the sample's position.
The cell marker for the Fluorescence-Activated Cell Sorting (FACS) of cells.

A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the enzymatic amplification (PCR, TMA, NASBA) of specific nucleic acids. The link can be a PMID, DOI or URL.
A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the material separation to recover the nucleic acid fraction from a sample
The total amount or size (volume (ml), mass (g) or area (m2) ) of sample collected

The estimated size of the genome prior to sequencing in base pairs (bp). Of particular importance in the sequencing of (eukaryotic) genome which could remain in draft form for a long or unspecified period
Volume (ml) or mass (g) of total collected sample processed for DNA extraction.
Cloning vector type(s) used in construction of libraries
Adapters provide priming sequences for both amplification and sequencing of the sample-library fragments. Both adapters should be reported; in uppercase letters
A brief description of any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment, or a link to the relevant protocol(s) performed
V4: e.g. filtering of seawater, storing samples in ethanol

V3: The design of the library including details of how it was constructed.
A unique alphanumeric reference or identifier for the sequencing protocol.
The name of the sequencing platform used for the experiment.
This refers to the machine or platform used for sequencing, with variations in throughput, read lengths, error rates, and application suitability.
Specify whether to expect single, paired, or other configuration of reads for sequencing
The type of read that contains the Unique Molecular Identifier (UMI) barcode.
The offset in sequence of the Unique Molecular Identifier (UMI) identifying barcode.
The size of the Unique Molecular Identifier (UMI) identifying barcode.
The type of read that contains the UMI barcode.
The offset in sequence of the cell identifying barcode.
The offset in sequence of the cell identifying barcode.
The actual nucleotide sequence obtained from Complementary DNA (cDNA) during sequencing.
The starting position of the Complementary DNA (cDNA) read within the entire sequence, indicating where the read begins after any barcodes or technical sequences.
The size of the Complementary DNA (cDNA) read.
Total number of clones in the library prepared for the project

Completeness score is typically based on either the fraction of markers found as compared to a database or the percent of a genome found as compared to a closely related reference genome. High Quality Draft: >90%, Medium Quality Draft: >50%, and Low Quality Draft: < 50% should have the indicated completeness scores
Total number of clones sequenced from the library
Total number of contigs in the cleaned/submitted assembly that makes up a given genome, SAG, MAG, or UViG

Reports the number of replicons in a nuclear genome of eukaryotes, in the genome of a bacterium or archaea or the number of segments in a segmented virus. Always applied to the haploid chromosome count of a eukaryote
The name of the file that was used to generate the analysis derived data.
Post analysis cell type or identity declaration based on expression profile or known gene function identified by the performer.

Performer defined measure of whether the read output
from the cell was included in the sequencing analysis. For example, cells might be excluded if a threshold percentage of reads did not map to the genome or if pre-sequencing quality measures were not passed.
Any other cell level measurement or annotation as result of the analysis.
Indicate version and include stable link to genome data (or attach genome fasta file).

Indicate version and include stable link. Also indicate if any modification to the original annotation has been applied (e.g. 3' UTR extension) and include modified annotation file employed in the analysis.
Indicate which features were filtered (i.e. protein coding, pseudo-genes, TCRs, etc.)
V4: e.g. Filtered to include only protein-coding genes

V3: Quantification using whole gene intervals or exons.
seqspec format
Reads/UMI
Statistics of the Reads or Unique Molecular Identifier (UMI).
Depending on number of cells recovered (not targeted) and technology
Show Unique Molecular Identifiers (UMIs) per barcode distribution and threshold applied
Unique Molecular Identifier (UMI) threshold used to discriminate cells from non-cells. Description of algorithm (if any) and parameters used to determine cells or non-cells.
V4: e.g. Threshold: 5 UMIs for cell detection

V3: Cells/nuclei discarded based on % mitochondrial reads, % rRNA reads, etc.
V4: e.g. Cells with >20% mitochondrial reads discarded

V3: Report % UMIs in background cell barcodes, and algorithm (if any) used to remove ambient RNA
V4: e.g. Ambient RNA removed if >5% UMIs in background barcodes

V3: Depending on number of cells recovered (not targeted) and technology
If carried out, show SNP partitioning quality (e.g. SNP UMAP embedding or covariance matrix), algorithm used
V4: e.g. SNP UMAP embedding using CellSNP

V3: Name/version of the assembly provided by the submitter that is used in the genome browsers and in the community
Do plasmids exist of significant phenotypic consequence (e.g. ones that determine virulence or antibiotic resistance). Megaplasmids? Other plasmids (borrelia has 15+ plasmids)
The assembly quality category is based on sets of criteria outlined for each assembly quality category.
Tool(s) used for assembly, including version number and parameters
V4: e.g. metaSPAdes;3.11.0;kmer set 21,33,55,77,99,121, default parameters otherwise

V3: Tool used for annotation, or for cases where annotation was provided by a community jamboree or model organism database rather than by a specific submitter
Method used to predict UViGs features such as ORFs, integration site, etc
Tools used for completion estimate, i.e. checkm, anvi'o, busco
Tool used to compare ORFs with database, along with version and cutoffs used
V4: e.g. HMMER3;3.1b2;hmmsearch, cutoff of 50 on score

V3: Standard operating procedures used in assembly and/or annotation of genomes, metagenomes or environmental sequences
If compared/integrated with existing datasets
If compared/integrated with existing datasets
If compared/integrated with existing datasets
If any newly developed code/software has been used in the processing and downstream analysis of the dataset.
V4: e.g. Source code is hosted on GitHub and includes custom algorithms for UMI count normalization. The repository can be found at: https://github.com/user/umi-normalization.

V3: Gene x cell matrix with UMI counts for each gene in each cell.
V4: e.g. The UMI count matrix is stored in a CSV file with gene IDs as rows (e.g., ENSG00000139618) and cell barcodes as columns (e.g., Cell_001, Cell_002). The matrix file is available at: https://example.com/umi_count_matrix.csv.

V3: Gene or transcript names should be listed as Ensembl (or other standardized ID), with gene short names in metadata.
Any functional annotation generated/used (gene names, GOs, structural domains, etc.).
V4: e.g. Functional gene annotations, including Gene Ontology (GO) terms, are provided in the metadata. For example, the gene 'ENSG00000139618' (BRCA1) is annotated with the GO term 'GO:0003674' (DNA binding).

V3: FASTA file with (or stable link to) the predicted proteins associated to genes in the UMI count matrix and matching IDs.
V4: e.g. The protein sequences for genes are provided in a FASTA file available at: https://example.com/protein_models.fasta, where each protein sequence is linked to the corresponding gene ID.

V3: Table mapping cell IDs to cluster/cell type/broad cell type annotations.
V4: e.g. Cell metadata includes information such as cell type annotations ('Tumor', 'Normal') and experimental conditions ('Control', 'Treatment'). This data is available in a table at: https://example.com/cell_metadata.csv.

V3: Expression tables that show normalised gene expression at the cluster or cell-type level.
V4: e.g. Normalised gene expression data at the cluster level is provided in a tab-delimited text file. For example, gene 'ENSG00000139618' (BRCA1) has expression values for clusters: Cluster_1: 1200, Cluster_2: 900. The full expression table is available at: https://example.com/cluster_level_expression.csv.

V3: Necessary to re-use and interpret the data. E.g. barcode information in complex, serial multiplexing protocols (clicktags).
V4: e.g. Barcode information used in multiplexing protocols is provided in a separate file, which can be accessed at: https://example.com/barcode_data.csv.

V3: A unique alphanumeric reference or identifier for the library preparation protocol used during the sequencing.
A unique alphanumeric reference or identifier for the sequencing protocol.
A unique alphanumeric identifier for this file
The name or accession of the file that contains read 1.
The name or accession of the file that contains read 2.
The name of the file that contains index 1.
The name of the file that contains index 2.
Result of a hash function calculated on the content of the read 1 file  to verify file integrity. Commonly used algorithms include MD5 and SHA-1. The checksums should be separated by a comma (,).
Result of a hash function calculated on the content of the read 2 file  to verify file integrity. Commonly used algorithms include MD5 and SHA-1. The checksums should be separated by a comma (,).
Result of a hash function calculated on the content of  the index 1 file  to verify file integrity. Commonly used algorithms include MD5 and SHA-1. The checksums should be separated by a comma (,).
Result of a hash function calculated on the content of  the index 2 file  to verify file integrity. Commonly used algorithms include MD5 and SHA-1. The checksums should be separated by a comma (,).

A file containing the known cell barcodes in the
dataset.
A filename or file name is a name used to uniquely identify a data file related to the study.
A file type is a name given to a specific kind of file. Common file types are fastq, gtf, fasta, bam, archive etc.
The name or accession of the file which quantifies the level of gene, transcript, or protein expression in a given biological sample or condition.
